Award.AwardTitle: Role of a CLE-WOX Intercellular Signaling Module in Controlling Polarity and Patterning During Leaf Development
Award.AbstractNarration: A central question in developmental biology is how groups of cells organize their activities to generate complex tissues and organs. Research has shown that small mobile proteins play key roles in conveying signals between neighboring cells, so that the cells can coordinate to generate patterns that make one end of an organ different from the other, and to produce the various functional tissues within the organ. Although these signaling proteins and their downstream pathways are well understood in animals, very little is known about the corresponding pathways in plants despite their clear importance for continuously producing new organs throughout the plant life cycle. The main research objective is to analyze the signaling pathways through which cell and tissue patterning events are organized during leaf formation in plants. This project will utilize genetic, molecular and biochemical methods to investigate the roles of the CLE5 and CLE6 signaling proteins in leaf patterning in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. The expected results are (1) the identification of genes that control CLE5/6 activity during early leaf development, (2) a thorough understanding of how CLE5/6 control leaf polarity and boundary formation, and (3) the discovery of key downstream genes in the pathway. Another important component is integrating research with education at the undergraduate and K-12 levels. UC Berkeley undergraduates from under-represented minority groups will assist with the project to obtain valuable research experience. In addition, a one week plant learning module will be organized for freshmen at the minority serving MetWest High School in Oakland, CA that will educate them about fundamental topics in biological science while providing hands-on exposure to plant biology through the use of simple research protocols. This study will provide new insights into the ways in which mobile signaling proteins direct the complex process of leaf formation, which can ultimately be used to improve agricultural and biofuels crop yield by maximizing leaf biomass.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Leaves make up the bulk of most plants that humans harvest for fuel and for consumption. These important plant organs, such as the wide leaves of lettuce, grow in reproducible patterns because of the activity of genes that direct the coordinated development of their cells. However, little is known about the identity or the precise function of the genes that signal between leaf cells to orchestrate their growth. This project has focused on determining the roles that two closely related members of the CLE family of signaling genes play during the Arabidopsis leaf development process.

The first set of experiments was designed to place the two CLE genes in the context of other genes and plant hormones known to control leaf development. We used several molecular methods to show that the CLE genes respond to the activity of genes that direct early events in leaf formation as well as to the hormone auxin that has long been recognized as a key substance for patterning the leaf as it develops. Next we investigated a potential regulatory relationship between the two CLE genes and two members of the WOX gene family that are expressed in leaves. Our analysis revealed that the two WOX genes together are important for activating expression of the CLE genes in leaf cells. Finally, we examined the function of the two CLE genes during leaf formation and found that each has a subtle but reproducible effect on the overall shape of the leaves formed by growing seedlings. This work provides the first identification of a role for signaling genes in leaf development and paves the way for future studies of the mechanism through which the CLE genes control leaf growth.

This project has supported the training of two postdoctoral scholars, a PhD student, and a female research assistant who has recently started graduate school. The principal investigator and other project members have also performed community outreach to broaden public knowledge of plant biology and the scientific process. They have participated in a USDA community garden project, working with 2nd graders from a nearby elementary school to grow vegetables for the local food bank; volunteered for the Be-A-Scientist Berkeley middle school science program; given talks to Oakland inner city middle school students to encourage their interest in science as a discovery process and as a career; and organized and taken part in Evolution Expo, a unique three day outreach program in Oakland, CA that partnered with NASA and the Chabot Space and Science Center to inspire under-privileged and under-represented minority school children into STEM.
